rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: Entity formation is not a checkbox. It's a foundation. Get it wrong and everything downstream is harder.
WHY THIS NEEDS ITS OWN MODEL
Most startups incorporate as an afterthought. File a Delaware LLC on Stripe Atlas,
sort out the cap table later, figure out the operating agreement when investors ask for it.
That's fine for a normal startup. This isn't a normal startup.
IonWave is:
• A DAO spinoff (novel governance structure, needs to be reflected in docs)
• A portfolio company of an infrastructure company (relationship needs to be clean)
• Giving equity to 5-10 people in the labor chain (cap table must be right from Day 1)
• Planning two simultaneous raises (entity structure affects both)
• Potentially operating across jurisdictions (Nilo in Brazil, team distributed)
Getting incorporation right means the CoS can raise without legal cleanup.
Getting it wrong means the first investor's lawyer finds problems that delay everything.
INCORPORATION WORKSTREAMS
I1
rows.col_3: Delaware C-Corp vs LLC vs other. Why Delaware. Tax implications. State registration requirements. Foreign qualification if needed.
rows.col_6: M0 locked (need to know the thesis before choosing entity type)

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I2
rows.col_3: Articles of incorporation/organization. EIN application. Registered agent. State filing. Certificate of formation.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I3
rows.col_3: Governance structure. Decision rights. Voting. DAO-compatible provisions. How the CM system maps to legal governance. Amendment procedures.
rows.col_6: I1 decided. CoS identified (they need to sign).

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I4
rows.col_3: Founder shares. Co-founder equity (PM). Option pool. VA bonus equity. Expert equity. CoS equity. Vesting schedules. Cliff periods. Dilution modeling for two raises.
rows.col_6: I1 and I3 done. All equity participants identified.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I5
rows.col_3: Business bank account. Mercury or equivalent. Payment processing. Bookkeeping setup (QBO). Initial capital deposit.
rows.col_6: I2 done (need EIN). CoS capital commitment confirmed.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I6
rows.col_3: Trade system IP assignment from Studio 4 to IonWave (license? transfer? limited rights?). Brand name. Domain. Trademark search/filing.
rows.col_6: I1 done. Relationship between IonWave and holding company defined.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I7
rows.col_3: How IonWave relates to the infrastructure company legally. Equity stake. License agreement for Trade system. Governance rights. Information rights. Anti-dilution.
rows.col_6: I1, I3, I4 done. Infrastructure company structure at least outlined.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I8
rows.col_3: VA agreement. PM co-founder agreement. Actor agreement. Product person contract. Expert engagement letters. IP assignment clauses in all agreements.
rows.col_6: I1 done. Each person hired needs an agreement.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: I9
rows.col_3: State business licenses. Sales tax registration (for D2C). Supplement-specific registrations if needed. Insurance (D&O, general liability, product liability).
rows.col_6: I2 done. Product category confirmed in M0.

rows.col_3: Data room setup. All formation docs organized. Cap table current. Financial projections linked. Diligence checklist pre-completed. Term sheet template ready.

rows.INCORPORATION — DOING IT RIGHT: THE LAWYER QUESTION
You need a startup lawyer for this. Not a general practitioner.
Specifically someone who has done:
• Delaware C-Corp formations for venture-backed startups
• Cap tables with multiple equity classes and option pools
• Operating agreements with non-standard governance (DAO-adjacent)
• IP licensing between related entities (holding co ↔ portfolio co)
Cost: $3-8K for full incorporation package (not hourly, flat fee).
Or: use Clerky / Stripe Atlas for formation + pay lawyer for operating agreement + cap table.
This is a Week 1 spend. The PM co-founder drives it. The VA supports with filings.
By end of Week 2, the entity should be fully formed, banked, and investor-ready.
WHAT 'DOING IT RIGHT' MEANS
Day 14 state: an investor's lawyer reviews the formation docs and finds zero issues.
That means:
• Entity type makes sense for planned raises
• Cap table is clean with all allocations documented and vesting in place
• Operating agreement reflects actual governance (including DAO/CM elements)
• IP relationship between IonWave and holding company is clear and clean
• All contractors have signed agreements with IP assignment
• Bank account is funded and bookkeeping is set up
• Data room is organized and investor-ready
This is the legal equivalent of 'complexity at launch.'
Most startups fix this stuff during diligence. We fix it before the first meeting.
